Dasein and temporality. Death, or "Being-towards-death," con- ditions Dasein and, in fact, makes it possible for Dasein to be revealed at all: "In the first instance, we must characterize Being-towards-death as Being-towards-a- possibility-indeed, towards a distinctive possibility of Dasein itself" (305)

Heidegger struggles toward this idea and, indeed, struggles toward finding a language appropriate to this idea in his sometimes tortured prose: "The closest closeness which one may have in being towards death as a possibility, is as far as possible from anything actual. The more unveiledly this possibility gets understood, the more purely does the understanding penetrate into it as the possibility of the impos- sibility of any existence at all" (307) 307

Symbolic Exchange and Death, Jean Baudrillard examines how the ini- tial taboo against death-a taboo that sanctifies the experience of death-has lost its power in contemporary culture. Modern culture has the lost the ability even to conceptualize the condition of death: "Strictly speaking, we no longer know what to do with them [the dead], since, today, it is not normal to be dead, and this is new. To be dead is an unthinkable anomaly; nothing else is as offensive as this.... The dead are no longer inflicted on any place or spacetime, they can find no resting place; they are thrown into a radical utopia" (126) 126

Bataille's writing attempts to overthrow philosophy by using philosophical concepts against themselves: "To laugh at philosophy ... henceforth calls for an entire 'dis- cipline,' an entire 'method of meditation' that acknowledges the philosopher's byways, understands his techniques, makes use of his rules, manipulates his cards, lets him deploy his strategy, appropriates his texts" (252) 252
Derrida acutely observes that the form of Bataille's philosophy will fold his discourse into a "strange shape" (253) 253
